channel.title: World News Today, Trending World News, Latest International News, World Breaking News - Times of India
channel.description: World News Today: Read the latest world news headlines, Current International breaking news world wide. In depth analysis and top news headlines world wide.

image.title: World News Today, Trending World News, Latest International News, World Breaking News - Times of India

item.title: 'Who stole his phone?': Bernie Sanders backs Trump's DOGE initiative, Elon Musk, netizens react
item.description: Senator Bernie Sanders endorsed President-elect Donald Trump's Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) initiative targeting Pentagon spending. He expressed concern over the Pentagon's $886 billion budget and audit failures. Sanders emphasized the necessity for change in federal and defense spending, highlighting that only 13 senators opposed the defense budget last year.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Hitman offered $71,000 to kill Canadian reporter who was covering his trial, admits to plot
item.description: A hitman, Frédérick Silva, convicted of multiple murders, admits to offering C$100,000 to kill Montreal crime reporter Daniel Renaud. The plot remained active for two months but was not executed. Quebec Premier François Legault denounced the plot, emphasizing continued police action against organized crime.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Prince William was jealous of Harry before his wedding: Report
item.description: Prince Harry revealed his brother, Prince William, was envious of his beard during Harry's wedding to Meghan. Despite military protocol, Harry received permission from the Queen to keep his beard, sparking a week-long quarrel between the brothers. The rule has since been amended, and William now sports a beard with approval.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: 'Miscarriage of justice': Trump slams Biden's presidential pardon for son Hunter
item.description: US President-elect Donald Trump criticized outgoing President Joe Biden's decision to pardon Hunter Biden for gun crimes and tax violations, labeling it a miscarriage of justice. Biden defended the pardon, stating the charges were politically motivated. Trump's reaction hints at possible pardons for January 6 rioters once he takes office.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Oxford's word of the year is 'brain rot'. What it means
item.description: Oxford's word of the year for 2024 is 'brain rot', highlighting concerns over excessive social media use and low-quality content. With over 37,000 votes, it reflects fears of declining mental capacity from trivial online material. The term, originating in 1854, gained popularity among Gen Z and Gen Alpha. Other shortlisted terms included 'demure', 'dynamic pricing', and 'slop'.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: What charges did Hunter Biden face before father and US President Joe pardoned him?
item.description: US President Joe Biden has granted a full pardon to his son, Hunter Biden, covering federal gun and tax charges from 2014 to 2024. Hunter faced convictions for firearm purchase under false claims and unpaid taxes. The pardon eliminates potential prison time, amidst claims of politically motivated prosecution.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: 'I hope Americans will understand': In U-turn, US president Joe Biden pardons son Hunter in gun, tax fraud charges
item.description: US President Joe Biden has granted a full and unconditional pardon to his son, Hunter Biden, for federal crimes committed between January 2014 and December 2024. Hunter Biden was convicted of gun and tax fraud. President Biden justified the pardon, citing unfair prosecution and political motivations behind the charges, emphasizing his son's recovery from addiction.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Former US National Security Advisor compares Trump’s pick of Kash Patel for FBI head to a Stalin-era appointment
item.description: Former US National Security Advisor John Bolton vehemently criticized President-elect Trump's nomination of Kash Patel for FBI Director, equating it to Soviet tactics. Bolton urged the Senate to unanimously reject Patel, who has expressed intentions to overhaul the FBI and has been a divisive figure in the past.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: 'Our brand is toxic': Former US Democratic lawmaker calls for 'complete reset' of party after Harris loss to Trump
item.description: Former US Democratic lawmaker Tim Ryan called for a significant overhaul of the party, labeling its image as 'toxic' in many areas. He stressed the need for a rebrand and a focus on working-class policies. Contrarily, Bernie Sanders and Nancy Pelosi hold differing views on the party's direction.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Why the happiest country can't stop greening
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Mohanty

item.title: Bus crash near French ski resort kills two, injures 33
item.description: A deadly bus accident near France's Porte-Puymorens ski resort resulted in the death of at least two people and injuries to 33 others, with seven critically injured. The bus, carrying 47 passengers, struck a cliff for reasons still under investigation. Rescue operations included over 120 personnel from France, Andorra, and Spain.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: DOGE duo of Musk and Ramaswamy criticise 'deep state' bureaucracy
item.description: Elon Musk and Vivek Ramaswamy criticized 'deep state' bureaucracy following MSNBC's comments on Kash Patel, labeling it a threat to democracy. Musk and Ramaswamy will lead the Department of Government Efficiency under Trump, aiming to reform federal bureaucracy and reduce wasteful spending by 2026.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Bangladesh HC acquits Zia’s son in 2004 grenade attack cases
‘Virtually zero risk’: Rabies expert questions killing of pet squirrel Peanut
item.description: The New York State DEC euthanised popular pet squirrel P’Nut and rescued raccoon Fred, sparking criticism from experts and animal rights advocates. Despite quarantine alternatives, the animals were killed for rabies testing following a questionable bite incident. Mark Longo, their caretaker, had been working to secure permits. Legal action and public outrage have ensued over the controversial act.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: 'Willingness to lie to govt': Vivek Ramaswamy criticises US immigration system
item.description: Vivek Ramaswamy criticizes the US immigration system for rewarding dishonesty over genuine asylum claims. He stresses the need for reform, echoing Trump’s policies on securing borders and enforcing the rule of law. Ramaswamy emphasizes lawful entry and opposes benefits for undocumented immigrants.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Elon Musk backs call for transparency after Kash Patel's FBI appointment
item.description: President-elect Donald Trump appoints Kash Patel as FBI Director, prompting social media calls for the declassification of contentious documents such as the 'Epstein list' and 'Diddy list.' Elon Musk supports the push for transparency, aligning with Patel's advocacy for revealing sensitive information for public accountability.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Prince William's equerry Rob Dixon steps down after four years of service
item.description: Lieutenant Commander Rob Dixon leaves his position as Prince William’s equerry after four years. Appointed in September 2020, Dixon facilitated several significant royal events. He returns to the Royal Navy, making way for Squadron Leader Mike Reynolds to assume the role.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Prince William finds solace in Ella’s company to escape Middleton family games
item.description: Prince William avoids the intense competitiveness of Middleton family game nights by taking James Middleton's dog, Ella, for a walk. Although William enjoys challenging Kate in private, he prefers to cheer from the sidelines during family games. William's love for animals and integration into the Middleton family highlight his close bond with them.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Is Stephan Hawking’s ‘gigantic ball of fire’ prediction about Earth coming true?
item.description: Physicist Stephen Hawking's predictions about Earth's future resurface as NASA warns of existential threats like climate change and overpopulation. Hawking urged action to colonize other planets to ensure humanity's survival, highlighting climate change, nuclear war, pandemics, AI, and asteroid impacts as key dangers. NASA emphasizes urgent action to mitigate irreversible climate damage.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Syrian government loses control of second-largest city Aleppo for first time in 13 years of civil war
item.description: Government forces lost control of Aleppo to the Islamist-dominated rebel alliance for the first time since the conflict began in 2011. The lightning assault was led by Hayat Tahrir al-Sham and coincided with a ceasefire in Lebanon. Kurdish forces expanded their control, exacerbating tensions with the rebels.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk
